description:
Human astrovirus (HAstV) is a small, non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus that belongs to the family Astroviridae. It is a common cause of acute gastroenteritis, primarily affecting children and the elderly.

The viral genome of HAstV is approximately 6.8 to 7.3 kilobases in length and encodes three open reading frames (ORFs). ORF1a and ORF1b encode the non-structural proteins involved in viral replication, while ORF2 encodes the capsid protein, which is the major structural component of the virus.

HAstV is transmitted primarily through the fecal-oral route, with contaminated food and water being the most common sources of infection. The virus can also be transmitted through direct contact with infected individuals or by aerosolized particles containing the virus.

The clinical symptoms of HAstV infection typically include diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and low-grade fever. The illness is generally self-limiting, with most cases resolving within a few days to a week. However, in some cases, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, the infection can lead to more severe complications, such as dehydration and neurological manifestations.

Diagnosis of HAstV infection is usually done through the detection of viral antigens or RNA in stool samples using techniques such as enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Treatment for HAstV infection is primarily supportive, focusing on maintaining hydration and electrolyte balance.

Prevention of HAstV infection relies on good hygiene practices, such as proper handwashing, food handling, and sanitation measures, as well as the development of effective vaccines, which are currently an area of ongoing research.
